ygData.subject: Re: Status of "Traits"
ygData.msgSnippet: Daniel, the short answer is that you can purge them if you see fit, although they were eventually used for at least one purpose.  I believe that most NEAT

Daniel, the short answer is that you can purge them if you see fit, altho=
ugh they were eventually used for at least one purpose.  I believe that mos=
t NEAT implementations do not have traits and work just fine so it's certai=
nly not critical.

However, the reason I included them is that I wanted a p=
lace to evolve future parameters for purposes not yet determined.  I also w=
anted them to be possible to reuse.  That is, the parameters would be eithe=
r node-centric or connection-centric, and more than one connection or node =
could point to the same trait, allowing a good set of parameters to be foun=
d and reused.

The particular application I had in mind was adaptive neural=
 networks, i.e. in which connection weights change over the network's lifet=
ime.  In that case, each connection would have its own evolved Hebbian rule=
 with its own parameters (such as learning rate).  The parameters of differ=
ent Hebbian rules could be evolved in traits, and the connections would poi=
nt to traits to assign themselves rules.

This idea was actually implemente=
d. I believe it actually is fully functional in the current rtNEAT distribu=
tion (by switching on a hardcoded flag that is set to off).  It did yield o=
ne publication in 2003 on evolving adaptive networks, which is here:

http:=
//nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=3D131

That publication also explains=
 traits and even has a diagram of how they work in figure 2.   However, ple=
ase note that in the paper we called them "Rules," since "Traits" is really=
 just a variable name in the code and not something very meaningful to some=
one reading a scientific paper.

I also think they may have been used in so=
me leaky-integrator-NEAT implementations (I think one is in the Files secti=
on here), although I am not completely certain whether it actually stored i=
ts parameters in the traits.  

So overall, yes, they did find a use, and I=
 think the general idea of leaving room for more (reusable) parameters made=
 the future expansion to adaptive networks easy.  However, they are also no=
t central or essential to NEAT, and it would function normally without them=
.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@...> wrote:
=
>
> Hi all,
> 
> Myself and a couple other guys are performing a complete o=
verhaul of JNeat.
>  One thing that always seems to be under foot is the co=
ncept of Traits.
>  Ken's documentation mentions that these were installed =
for some future
> purposes.  I'm curious what became of them, and specifica=
lly if they are now
> considered to be an important feature of the NEAT alg=
orithm.  If we
> permitted ourselves to purge them from JNeat, would they b=
e missed?
> 
> Regards,
> Daniel
>
